Greetings everyone,
and welcome back to my channel.

6.text:
Today I'm going to be doing a video for you
that is not on fashion or beauty,

10.text:
or anything related to those subjects,
but it's one relating to disability.

14.text:
Now if you remember last year, I did a video called
The Top 10 Misconceptions Around Sight Loss.

20.text:
And this video was so popular,
that it got a massive reception

23.text:
from people like Scope, the RNIB,
Guide Dogs, it was big.

27.text:
And I was so pleased with the reception that it got,
that I've decided to make a sequel to that video.

33.text: Now this one's going to be called The Things That You Should Never Say Or Do To A Visually Impaired Person.

38.text:
Now I'm going to just throw out
a little disclaimer here to start off with.

41.text:
I don't mean this video to be an insult to anyone,
I don't want to patronise anyone,

45.text: I don't want to make anyone feel bad.

47.text: If you find that you might have said or done one of these things to a visually impaired person,

51.text:
don't worry about it, everyone makes mistakes in life.
This is just a video to culture you

56.text: on some of the things that you shouldn't do,

58.text:
and just ways that you can, you know,
talk to people with visual impairments,

61.text:
and if you want to help them, ways that
you can do it in an effective way,

64.text:
that does not patronise them or
make them feel bad about their disability.

68.text: To start off with, number 1 is waving your hand in front of a visually impaired person's face,

73.text: or asking them "How many fingers am I holding up?"

76.text:
This is so annoying! Like, I don't know why
people feel that they need to do that.

81.text: Like, whether they're just trying to test whether you're lying or not about how much sight you have,

86.text: whether they're trying to be an optician, whether they just want to know if you can see anything.

90.text:
You know, it's just a bit of an insult to be honest.
Like, I don't have a guide dog for the fun of it.

96.text:
I love her to bits, and she's
my favourite thing in the world,

99.text: but I don't have a cane or a guide dog for fun.

102.text:
I don't use Voiceover for fun. I do it
because I genuinely can't see very well,

106.text:
and you waving your hand in front of my face
is not going to change the fact that

110.text: I have got 10% remaining vision in my left eye.

113.text: So just please don't do that in future. If you're not too sure about how much sight someone's got

117.text: then just ask them how much sight they've got.

120.text: Because that's just a better way than just doing this,

123.text: or "How many fingers am I holding up?"

125.text:
Number 2 is asking a person if they can see
something, if they're asking for directions

131.text: Now, if someone with a visual impairment - like who maybe has a guide dog or a long cane -

135.text: comes up to you and says "Excuse me, how do I get to the town centre?" for example,

140.text: I don't think it's good to say "Can you see that?"

144.text:
Instead you could say "How much can you see?",
"How far ahead of you can you see?",

148.text:
"Can you see that big bus stop?",
"Can you see that big red thing in the distance?"

152.text:
"Can you see... blah, blah, blah."
Or if not - "What would help you?",

157.text:
"If I told you what things to listen out for,
or what things to feel out for with your cane?"

161.text:
Or you could also just say to them "if you
walk at a slow distance for about 2 minutes,

165.text: you'll reach so-and-so, and then cross the road, and then you'll reach a certain distance."

169.text:
If a person's got a guide dog for instance,
they might be able to tell a lot by themselves.

173.text:
So if you just tell them certain directions
to go in, that might be enough.

177.text:
But it's always worth asking a person how
much they can see, what they can see.

182.text: if they can't see, what would help them?

184.text:
But never to surmise that a person
can see what's in front of them,

187.text:
because nine times out of ten,
they might not be able to.

190.text:
You giving them visual information
might not be the best thing for them.

194.text:
So, just refrain from that in future,
and instead think to yourself

197.text:
"How would I manage if I was visually impaired?
What would I want this person to tell me?"

202.text:
Because that will nine times out of ten
be the better response to give.

205.text:
Number 3 is my most hated one,
it's my pet hate above all others.

210.text: And if any of you have done this one, I would really consider refraining from this in the future,

215.text:
and that is speaking to the person that's with
the disabled person, as opposed to them.

220.text:
What I mean by this is that, say
for instance a person comes up to you

224.text: when you're visually impaired or disabled,

226.text:
sometimes what they will do is they
will speak to the person and ask them

230.text:
what their level of vision is, or what their disability is,
or, you know, say something like

235.text:
"It's such a shame for that person." or
"Oh, it's so sad that they've ended up like this."

239.text: or "Oh, do they want a sugar in their tea?"

242.text:
And that is just a really, really, really
annoying thing to do,

246.text:
and it's very commonplace
in the world of disability.

248.text:
Asking a person that's with the person
how many sugars they want in their tea

252.text: is removing their ability to talk to you.

254.text: It's like you're saying that they can't speak for themselves just because they've got a disability,

258.text:
which is not true. Ask them. Don't ask
the person that's with them. Ask them.

262.text:
Speak to them like you would anyone else,
because like anyone else

266.text:
they have got thoughts and opinions,
and they can speak to you,

268.text:
[Louder] And they can tell you if
they want sugar in their tea! [Laughs]

272.text: And when my mother's been with me on these occasions, and they've done it to her,

275.text:
and they've spoke to her about
my disability and not me,

278.text:
she will just turn it round on them,
she will make them speak to me.

281.text: She'll say "Well Emily, why don't you tell this person."

284.text:
or "Emily, why don't you explain
what your vision is to this person?"

289.text: Because it's just, when a person does that, they might not be doing it intentionally to offend people,

293.text: they just might be a bit scared of the topic of disability, and they might not want to

298.text: speak to the disabled person themselves.

300.text: Even though this is wrong, and they shouldn't do this,  it's just something you've got to remember.

303.text: Don't be scared about disability, and don't feel like you can't speak to a disabled person

307.text: about their disability. You can. It's just about having the right words to say, and knowing how to say it.

312.text: So number 4 which I'm going to talk about is one that.. it's both funny but it is very serious as well.

319.text:
And that is grabbing a visually impaired person
without warning.

322.text:
Now, people usually do this if they're
trying to guide you somewhere.

325.text: Say for instance they see a person on the street and they're visually impaired,

328.text: and they look like they need some help.

330.text: They might go up to the person and just grab them by the arm and try and help them

333.text:
and try and guide them somewhere.
This is never the thing to do.

336.text: Imagine you're visually impaired. You're walking across a street at night, minding your own business,

341.text:
wanting to get home, and then someone
comes up and grabs you by the arm.

345.text: You don't know whether that person is trying to help you or is going to try and murder you.

349.text:
Now that would be a very scary situation for anyone,
but especially someone who's visually impaired.

354.text: So if you're trying to help a person who's visually impaired, and try and guide them somewhere,

358.text: the best thing to do is to go up to them, introduce yourself, say your name, who you are,

362.text: and ask them "Do you need any help?"

365.text:
If they say no, that's fine, you can
get on with your own business.

367.text:
But never go up to them and just
randomly grab them by the arm,

370.text: because it would be your own fault if they turned round and punched you in the face out of sheer fright.

374.text:
Now, just remember that for future reference.
Go up and introduce yourself,

378.text: Never go up and grab someone.

380.text:
Now number 5 kind of relates
to the last one, and that is

383.text:
don't assume that all visually
impaired people need help.

386.text: Now, it's always good if you go up to a person and ask them if they need help if they're visually impaired,

390.text: because that's just something really lovely to do.

393.text:
And I'm not saying that we don't appreciate it,
because I can speak on behalf of

397.text:
a lot of visually impaired people.
We really appreciate the public's help.

400.text:
But the thing not to do is if they say to you
"No, we don't need any help.",

404.text: don't presume that they still do, and try and badger them the whole time if they need help.

408.text:
Although it's lovely, and I know
they're just trying to be nice,

411.text:
if I say I don't need any help,
I don't need any help.

414.text:
Not everyone with visual impairments
is completely blind.

417.text: But not only that, they might really feel very confident in their natural environment,

420.text: and they just might not need any help.

422.text:
So, just don't presume that everyone with
visual impairments does need help,

425.text:
and if they say no, they just genuinely mean it
because they don't need any help.

429.text: Number 6 - saying the words "It's over there."

433.text: Oh my god! I hate it when I go into my parents' bedroom and I ask my mum

440.text:
"Where's that... you know... where's that remote?"
and she says "It's over there."

443.text: Or I say to someone in a supermarket "Where can I find the cakes?" and they say "They're over there."

448.text: I'm visually impaired. The word "there" is an infinite concept. "There" could mean anything!

454.text:
It can mean north-west, it could mean south-west,
it can mean up, it could mean down,

459.text:
it could mean stuffed down my bra,
it could mean anything!

463.text: So it's just not a helpful concept.

466.text:
What would be helpful is if you said
"It's over to your left a couple of paces."

469.text:
or "It's behind you."
or "It's just in front of you slightly."

473.text:
or, you know, say for instance you visualised
yourself in a clock, it would be to say

477.text:
it's over in the direction of 1 o'clock,
or 2 o'clock, or 6 o'clock.

481.text:
The thing that is not helpful is to say to me
"It's over there."

483.text: because I have no idea of what "over there" means.

487.text:
Because the word "there" means
absolutely nothing to me.

492.text: Number 7 would be refusing access to a person with a guide dog, or an assistance dog indeed.

499.text: This one's very serious. Now, if you are a shop owner, or someone who has refused access to

504.text:
a visually impaired person, due to the fact
that they've got a guide dog, this is illegal.

508.text:
It's discrimination, and it's not allowed.
It is not permitted in the UK.

513.text: A person with a guide dog, it's a necessity. They need that guide dog to get them around from A to B,

518.text:
and it's their mobility aid. And they are
exempt from being excused from anywhere.

524.text: Guide dogs are allowed in any public place.

526.text: You have to remember that that dog is there for a reason, that dog is there to help that person,

530.text: and you refusing a visually impaired person because of a guide dog is discrimination against their disability,

535.text: and it's not right, and you will get penalised for it.

538.text:
So please don't do that to a visually impaired person,
because the consequences are very great.

545.text:
I get it a lot. People will say to me
"Oh, can she have a biscuit?" or, you know,

550.text:
"Can she have a bit of my banana?"or
"Can she have this?", "Can she have that?"

554.text:
If a guide dog's working,
if their harness is up and they're working,

557.text:
and they're taking the person from A to B,
they are not allowed food,

561.text: because guide dogs as a rule are very foodie animals.

564.text: All dogs are, but especially labradors, which is the predominant breed that guide dogs use.

568.text:
They are very foodie, and if
you start feeding them food,

571.text:
they will not be doing the job
that they're supposed to be doing,

574.text: which is guiding that person safely and effectively

576.text:
So to put this into perspective,
let me throw out an example here.

580.text:
Say for instance you go and
eed that guide dog a chip.

582.text:
They've got the flavour of what a chip tastes like,
and they will know what it smells like.

586.text: When that guide dog owner is taken out for a walk with the guide dog, they might see chips in the road.

591.text:
They're not gonna be concentrating
on guiding that person any more,

594.text: they're going to be trying to pull that guide dog owner into the road to get the chips.

597.text:
And this is of course really dangerous,
because a person with a visual impairment

601.text:
relies on that guide dog to take them everywhere,
and to get them from A to B safely.

604.text:
So, just please remember the
consequences that will come after it,

607.text: because that might severely inhibit that guide dog's ability to learn and to guide the person,

612.text: and the guide dog owner's safety.

614.text: Number 9 - Talking to a person with a visual impairment as if they were stupid,

617.text:
or as if they didn't know
what you were talking about.

620.text: A person with a visual impairment is in no way, shape or form prevented to understand what you're saying.

626.text: We are completely coherent in our thoughts and what we say, and we are able to talk to you on a level.

632.text:
Don't feel the need to shout at us as if we can't hear,
or as if we can't understand you, like:

637.text:
[Louder and exaggerated] "Do... You...
Want... Some... Help?" or "Are... You... O... K?

642.text:
I have got this before, and I'm not lying,
I have had people talk to me like this.

646.text:
A person with a visual impairment can
talk to you just like you would anyone else,

650.text:
and if you want to ask them a question,
just ask them normally.

653.text:
Don't feel the need to have to ask them
as if they were on some LSD trip,

657.text: because that's just never the right thing to do.

660.text:
Just remember, talk to them normally
and everything should be fine.

664.text: Number 10 - Presuming that a visually impaired person does not have any quality of living.

670.text:
People have come up to me in the past
and they've said things like

672.text:
"Can you do anything? Can you work? Do you just
sit indoors all day and listen to the radio?"

678.text:
And no, the answer to that is
I have a very good standard of living.

681.text:
I am at university studying for a degree,
I have a very good social life,

685.text:
I am a journalist, I have a lot of fun,
and I really enjoy my life.

690.text:
I personally think I've got a good quality of life,
as do a lot of other people with visual impairments.

695.text: Just being visually impaired does not mean that you can't live any more, and that you can't have fun.

700.text: You are still able to do all the things that you were able to do beforehand, but just in a different way.

705.text:
You can enjoy comedy, you can enjoy watersports,
you can enjoy film, you can enjoy books,

710.text:
just like anyone else. Just because
you might do things in a different way,

713.text:
it does not mean to say that you are not able
to have a good standard of living.

717.text: And don't let anyone else convince you otherwise.

719.text: The last one is moving things without warning,

723.text:
or walking away from a visually impaired person
without telling them.

726.text: Now people might do this to me. Sometimes they might move say, for instance, a book or something,

730.text: or they might move, you know, my laptop or whatever, or they might move a drink.

735.text:
and I've not been aware that they've done it,
and I might end up

738.text:
knocking the contents of that drink all over the floor,
or knocking all the popcorn everywhere.

742.text: And, if I do that, it's really quite embarrassing for me, and it just could have been easily avoided.

747.text:
If you'd just had said to me
"Emily, I've moved that over to your left.",

751.text:
or "I've moved that just ahead of you a little bit.",
then I'll be aware of where that thing is,

755.text:
and I wont' be inclined to knock it over
or to do some haphazard, you know,

759.text:
arm movement that means that
I've just had a total disaster.

763.text: And if you walk away from a person with a visual impairment halfway through a conversation,

767.text:
they might still be there thinking you're there,
and continue to talk to you, like

771.text: "Oh, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, yeah, la, la, la."

774.text:
or "Do you know if this bus is coming yet?
I don't think it is."

777.text:
And if a person sees a visually impaired
person talking to themself,

781.text:
this henceforth starts off these ideas in their head
that people with visual impairments are mad.

787.text: We just might have a totally different image in our head of what's going on to what you do.

791.text:
So just remember, if you have finished
a conversation with that person,

795.text:
just say "Oh, I'm off now. Nice to see ya.
Blah, blah, blah. Toodle-oo." And just walk off.

800.text:
Don't end the conversation halfway through.
Always end it on a buh-bye and go.

806.text:
So that concludes the top things you should never
say or do to a visually impaired person.

810.text: I really hope you enjoyed it and that it's given you some insight as to what not to do, and what to do.

815.text:
People with visual impairments, 
I hope this gave you a few chuckles.
